channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2018 The New York Times Company

item.title: What Keeps Xi Jinping Awake at Night
item.media:description: A Chinese Navy display in the South China Sea in April. President Xi Jinping of China has warned military officials that they risk being eclipsed technologically by the United States.
item.description: A new book of the Chinese leader’s remarks on national security highlights his worries about technology, the internet and risks of financial meltdown.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY and PAUL MOZUR

item.title: Israel and Iran, Newly Emboldened, Exchange Blows in Syria Face-Off
item.media:description: Missiles seen from Damascus, Syria, on Thursday.
item.description: The cross-border exchanges — the most serious from each side over Iran’s presence in Syria — took place a day after the Americans withdrew from the Iran nuclear accord.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER and DAVID M. HALBFINGER

item.title: Philippine Court Removes Chief Justice, a Critic of Duterte
item.media:description: Supporters of Maria Lourdes Sereno, the ousted chief justice of the Philippines, rallying in front of the Supreme Court in Manila on Friday.
item.description: Chief Justice Maria Lourdes Sereno questioned the president’s drug war “watch list” and martial law. After he called her an “enemy,” she is out.
item.dc:creator: FELIPE VILLAMOR

item.title: South Korea Hands Kim Jong-un a Path to Prosperity on a USB Drive
item.media:description: North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, left, and President Moon Jae-in of South Korea at the Demilitarized Zone in the South last month. During the meeting, Mr. Moon handed Mr. Kim a USB drive with an economic plan for the Korean Peninsula.
item.description: South Korea’s leader gave Mr. Kim a USB drive that laid a plan for new railways and power plants for North Korea should it abandon nuclear weapons.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: 10 Years Ago in Sichuan, a Quake Killed 69,000. Should China Be Thankful?
item.media:description: A student who survived the Sichuan earthquake in 2008 mourning in Beichuan, China, last month at a memorial for the many victims.
item.description: An online backlash has erupted over officials’ attempt to mark the disaster with a day of gratitude to the government, instead of by honoring the dead.
item.dc:creator: TIFFANY MAY

item.title: As Nuclear Sanctions Loom, ‘Normal Life’ Is Elusive for Iranians
item.media:description: A Tehran bazaar after President Trump announced that the United States was pulling out of the nuclear deal.
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.description: Our correspondent walked the streets of Tehran after the United States pulled out of the Iran deal. “We have to go with the flow,” one man said.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: In Malaysia, the Old Prime Minister Promises a New Order
item.media:description: Mahathir Mohamad, 92, was sworn in on Thursday as Malaysia’s prime minister, a post he held from 1981 to 2003. He has vowed to reform the system he helped install.
item.description: After a day of drama and tension following a historic election, Mahathir Mohamad, 92, took the oath of office, vowing to reform the system he helped install.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK

item.title: Why Iran and Israel Are Clashing in Syria
item.media:description: Israeli tanks on Thursday in the Golan Heights near Syria.
item.description: A long-simmering conflict escalated dramatically overnight with Israel targeting the military infrastructure Iran has been building up in Syria.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Moscow Journal: A River of Pictures of the Dead From Russia’s Sacred War
item.media:description: Russians took part in the March of the Immortal Regiment in Moscow on Wednesday, carrying portraits of family members who fought in World War II.
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.description: Ten million Russians marched this week in Immortal Regiment parades, carrying portraits of relatives who died in World War II, a conflict that touched nearly every family in the country.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Malaysian Prime Minister Says Jailed Opposition Leader Will Be Pardoned
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad of Malaysia, center, at the National Mosque in Kuala Lumpur on Friday.
item.description: A day after being sworn in, Mahathir Mohamad says the king has agreed to pardon Anwar Ibrahim, setting the stage for his political return.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: U.S. Takes a Risk: Old Iraqi Enemies Are Now Allies
item.media:description: Members of the Badr Organization, a Shiite movement with deep ties to Iran, praying in Hilla, Iraq, last month. Two leaders of the group who are poised to play key roles in the next Iraqi government want military help from the United States.
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.description: In Iraq, the United States is training and sharing intelligence with former members of Iranian-backed militias that once fought and killed Americans.
item.dc:creator: MARGARET COKER
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: 7 Dead in Australia’s Worst Mass Shooting Since 1996
item.media:description: A rural property in Western Australia where the police said seven people, including four children, were found dead on Friday from gunshot wounds.
item.description: Australia’s strict gun control laws, enacted after a massacre in 1996, are often cited as an example of how legislation can limit mass shooting deaths.
item.dc:creator: GIOVANNI TORRE

item.title: Britain Apologizes for Role in Libyan Dissident’s C.I.A. Nightmare
item.media:description: A former Libyan dissident, Abdel Hakim Belhaj, spoke at a news conference in Turkey on Thursday after receiving an apology from the British government for its role in his kidnapping and torture.
item.description: “You were both subjected to appalling treatment,” the government told a Libyan couple who were tortured after the C.I.A. snatched them in 2004 on a tip from British spies.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Syria, North Korea, Malaysia: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and VIRGINIA LOZANO

item.title: As Gaza Teeters on Precipice, a Hamas Leader Speaks Out
item.media:description: The Hamas leader in the Gaza Strip, Yehya Sinwar, center, spoke to protesters at the fence separating the Gaza Strip from Israel last month.
item.description: Yehya Sinwar, leader of the militant group in Gaza, is preparing for what could be the climax of weeks of protests at the fence separating the Gaza Strip from Israel.
item.dc:creator: DAVID M. HALBFINGER and IYAD ABUHEWEILA

item.title: Rome Is Burning (or at Least Its Buses Are)
item.media:description: The first of two buses to catch fire in Rome on Tuesday. The city has had 10 bus fires so far this year, according to local news media estimates.
item.description: Romans are used to the buses running late. But recently, they are catching fire. What’s a reporter just trying to get to work supposed to do?
item.dc:creator: GAIA PIANIGIANI

item.title: Military Inquiry Finds Soldiers Were Unprepared in Deadly Niger Ambush
item.media:description: An American military exercise last month with local forces in Ouallam, Niger.
item.description: An investigation of the Oct. 4 deaths of four American soldiers describes misleading plans and lax oversight for a mission that ended in a firefight with extremists.
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER, THOMAS GIBBONS-NEFF and ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Army Special Forces (Green Berets)

item.title: With Jail Sentences and Corporate Flameouts, China Is Tackling its Debt
item.media:description: The offices of the Anbang Insurance Group in Beijing. Wu Xiaohui, the company’s founder, was sentenced to 18 years in prison on Thursday.
item.description: An 18-year prison term for the founder of Anbang Insurance Group is part of Beijing’s effort to tame risky borrowing without hurting the broader economy.
item.dc:creator: ALEXANDRA STEVENSON

item.title: Trump Exults in Release of Prisoners and a Date Next Month With Kim Jong-un
item.media:description: President Trump on Tuesday at the White House. On Thursday, he posted on Twitter about his upcoming meeting with Kim Jong-un, North Korea’s leader: “We will both try to make it a very special moment for World Peace!”
item.description: The president announced the summit meeting’s date and place in a Twitter post hours after meeting the three Americans freed by North Korea at Joint Base Andrews.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER and KATIE ROGERS

item.title: Deadly Uprising by ISIS Followers Shakes Indonesia’s Prison System
item.media:description: Police officers outside a high-security compound in Depok, Indonesia, on Thursday. Five guards were killed in a prisoner uprising at a detention center in the compound that highlighted serious flaws in the handling of terrorism detainees.
item.description: Five guards were killed in a riot at a high-security detention center that highlighted serious flaws in the handling of terrorism detainees.
item.dc:creator: JOE COCHRANE
item.category: Institute for Policy Analysis of Conflict
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: David Goodall, 104, Scientist Who Fought to Die on His Terms, Ends His Life
item.media:description: The Australian scientist David Goodall the day before he was to take a lethal dose of barbiturates in Basel, Switzerland.
item.description: Mr. Goodall wanted to die because of his deteriorating health, and he flew to Switzerland to find legal services to assist him, choosing Beethoven for his last song.
item.dc:creator: YONETTE JOSEPH and ILIANA MAGRA

item.title: Australian Officer Suspended After Police Car Hits Aboriginal Man
item.description: The release of a video showing a pedestrian being struck in Perth has stirred outrage and a police inquiry.
item.dc:creator: GIOVANNI TORRE and ISABELLA KWAI

item.title: Malaysia’s Election: What Happened, and What’s Next
item.media:description: Mahathir Mohamad, expected to be Malaysia’s new prime minister, with a letter to the king, who must officially name the next leader.
item.description: An upset victory for the opposition, and questions about the country’s political future, have put a new focus on Malaysia’s political system.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Kenya Dam Break Wipes Out Villages, Killing Dozens
item.media:description: Searching for survivors amid the flooding on Thursday in and around Solai, a cluster of villages about 110 miles northwest of the Kenyan capital, Nairobi.
item.description: The disaster about 110 miles northwest of the capital, Nairobi, left 500 families homeless and set off a scramble to find the missing and identify the dead.
item.dc:creator: REUBEN KYAMA and RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA
item.category: International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies

item.title: Australia Diary: The Fairest Cake of Them All
item.media:description: Kate's son's ladybird cake.
item.description: Readers share their favorite creations from “The Australian Women’s Weekly Children’s Birthday Cake Cookbook.”
item.dc:creator: DIANA OLIVA CAVE

item.title: Cakes Galore
item.description: All kinds of sugary concoctions from Australia Diary readers.

item.title: Overlooked No More: Leticia Ramos Shahani, a Philippine Women’s Rights Pioneer
item.media:description: Leticia Ramos Shahani, center, during a commencement ceremony at the Philippine Military Academy in 1997, when she was a senator. Her brother, Fidel V. Ramos, left, was president at the time.
item.description: Shahani, who died in 2017, worked to advance women’s causes in her native Philippines and around the world.
item.dc:creator: JENNIFER JETT

item.title: Letter 57: Australia Is Rich, Strong and Afraid of the World
item.media:description: United States Marines marching in Darwin, Australia, on Anzac Day in 2017.
item.media:credit: David Dare Parker for The New York Times
item.description: What I learned from Australia’s new federal budget about how the country sees its global role. This week’s Australia Letter.
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: Iran Fires Rockets Into Golan Heights From Syria, Israelis Say
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers in the Golan Heights on Wednesday. Israel said early Thursday that Iranian forces in Syria had fired missiles at its forward positions.
item.description: Iranian forces fired about 20 rockets into the Golan Heights, the Israeli authorities said. They said they had responded to the attack.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Spain Tries to Foil Re-election of Catalonia’s Fugitive Separatist Leader
item.media:description: The fugitive separatist leader from Catalonia, Carles Puigdemont, second from left, and fellow Catalan politicians meeting in Germany last week. Mr. Puigdemont is fighting extradition to Spain.
item.description: The government asked the Constitutional Court to invalidate a Catalan law allowing Carles Puigdemont to be voted into office in absentia.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: North Korea, Iran, Gina Haspel: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and DAVID SCULL

item.title: Relatives of American Prisoners in Iran Ask: What Now?
item.media:description: Siamak Namazi, one of five Americans known to be held by Iran, near San Francisco in 2006.
item.description: The release of Americans in North Korea, after President Trump quit the Iran nuclear deal, stirred hope and despair among relatives of Americans imprisoned in Iran.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Five Top ISIS Officials Captured in U.S.-Iraqi Sting
item.media:description: Iraqi state television broadcast images of four of the men arrested in the operation.
item.description: After an aide to the Islamic State’s leader was captured in Turkey, the C.I.A. and Iraqi intelligence used him to lure other operatives, Iraqi officials say.
item.dc:creator: MARGARET COKER
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Tech Fix: How to Pack and Prepare Your Smartphone for Traveling This Summer
item.description: Your smartphone is a helpful travel companion. Before taking it abroad, here’s a list of things to pack and do to ensure a problem-free trip.
item.dc:creator: BRIAN X. CHEN

item.title: U.S. Pullout From Iran Nuclear Deal May Unsettle Oil Markets
item.media:description: A natural gas refinery in Asalouyeh, Iran. Energy experts say President Trump’s decision to pull out of the Iran nuclear deal could prompt a cascade of unpredictable events in oil markets.
item.description: Saudi Arabia and Russia may offset any reduction in Iranian exports, but if prices rise, one of the beneficiaries could be Iran itself.
item.dc:creator: CLIFFORD KRAUSS

item.title: Green Slime on the Taj Mahal? Court Blames Slow, Botched Cleanup
item.media:description: The exterior of the Taj Mahal in northern India has been deteriorating for years. Officials overseeing a restoration project blame insect slime and pollution.
item.description: India’s Supreme Court on Wednesday reprimanded the Archaeological Survey of India for failing to protect the Taj Mahal from dirty feet and insects.
item.dc:creator: KAI SCHULTZ and HARI KUMAR

item.title: Chinese Tech Giant on Brink of Collapse in New U.S. Cold War
item.media:description: ZTE’s logo on a building in Shanghai. The firm said it had ceased “major operating activities” after the Trump administration banned it from using components made in the United States.
item.description: The electronics firm ZTE has found success in the American market like few other Chinese technology brands have. Now it is fighting for its life.
item.dc:creator: RAYMOND ZHONG

item.title: Rome Journal: ‘Extra’ Cardinals Invade the Vatican (Blessings Not Included)
item.media:description: Extras on the streets around the Vatican for the filming of a Netflix drama about the relationship between Francis and Benedict during the papal transition of 2013.
item.description: Tourists and even some Vatican officials were baffled as the realistic-looking cardinals — extras in a Netflix production — seemed to take over the streets.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: Chocolate Spills, and Brown Goo Closes a Polish Highway
item.description: Firefighters used hot water to wash off the sticky brown goo that poured over a main road between Warsaw and Poznan on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: North Korea Frees American Prisoners, Lifting Hurdle to Nuclear Talks
item.media:description: From left: Kim Dong-chul, Tony Kim and Kim Hak-song on TV news reports in Seoul, South Korea, this month. North Korea released the three men, all American citizens, on Wednesday.
item.description: The president said that North Korea had released the American detainees in a good-will gesture as the two countries prepare for a meeting between their leaders.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Iran May Step Up Nuclear Program, Supreme Leader Says
item.media:description: Lawmakers burned an American flag in the Iranian Parliament in Tehran on Wednesday. “Now all Iranians blame the United States for their troubles,” said one hard-line political analyst.
item.media:credit: Iranian Parliament, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei reacted angrily to President Trump’s withdrawal from a 2015 deal, hinting that his country would now step up its nuclear program.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Militants Kill 15 in Afghan Attacks, as Taliban Expand Their Control
item.media:description: Afghan security forces at the site of an attack in Kabul, Afghanistan, on Wednesday.
item.description: Insurgents launched two attacks in Kabul, and one in western Afghanistan. Also, an airstrike killed six policemen, and officials blamed American forces.
item.dc:creator: JAWAD SUKHANYAR and ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Walmart Takes Control of India’s Flipkart in E-Commerce Gamble
item.media:description: E-commerce company Flipkart's headquarters in Bangalore, India.
item.description: The $16 billion deal will put America’s largest operator of physical retail stores in direct competition with Amazon in a promising but risky market.
item.dc:creator: VINDU GOEL

item.title: Europe, Again Humiliated by Trump, Struggles to Defend Its Interests
item.media:description: With his Iran decision, as on climate and trade, President Trump has split sharply with strong allies.
item.description: With his Iran decision, as on climate and trade, President Trump has split sharply with strong allies. There are signs that their patience is wearing thin.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Trump’s Iran Decision Sends North Korea a Signal. Was It the Right One?
item.media:description: If President Trump wants to persuade North Korea to give up its nuclear arsenal, abandoning the Iran accord could produce the opposite outcome, some analysts say.
item.description: By pulling out of the deal, some analysts say, President Trump has shown the U.S. to be an untrustworthy negotiating partner before a meeting with Kim Jong-un.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: Fighting for the Palme d’Or, and the Right to Fly to Cannes
item.media:description: Jafar Panahi in Tehran in 2010. His latest film, “Three Faces,” produced in spite of an official ban on his making films in or leaving Iran, is in competition for the top prize at this year’s Cannes Film Festival.
item.description: Two directors in the running for the film festival’s top prize, Kirill S. Serebrennikov of Russia and Jafar Panahi of Iran, are barred from travel by their governments.
item.dc:creator: FARAH NAYERI

item.title: ISIS-Linked Indonesian Jail Riot Ends as Police Raid Cellblock
item.media:description: Police officers patrolling in Depok, south of Jakarta, Indonesia, on Wednesday, a day after a riot erupted at a detention center that held terrorism suspects.
item.description: Counterterrorism officers forced a mass surrender, blowing out a cellblock’s walls in a search for bombs planted in a deadly uprising.
item.dc:creator: JOE COCHRANE
item.category: Institute for Policy Analysis of Conflict
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: European Companies Rushed to Invest in Iran. What Now?
item.media:description: A Peugeot 206 at the state-run Iran Khodro automobile manufacturing plant near Tehran. European officials want to protect their companies by finding ways to shield them from American sanctions while they continue doing business in Iran.
item.description: They moved quickly to strike deals after sanctions ended. But dreams of a thriving Iranian market were in doubt even before the U.S. decided to exit the nuclear accord.
item.dc:creator: JACK EWING and STANLEY REED
